repnme.cdata!:
Kazakhstan - Irrigation and Drainage
            Improvement Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey a satisfactory project
            outcome, likely sustainability, and high institutional
            development impacts, as well as satisfactory performances by
            the Bank and Borrower. A more realistic rating of the
            project outcome would be "more than satisfactory"
            considering the Highly Satisfactory rating as the top of the
            scale. This is so because all project development objectives
            were met as shown in Section 4, the outcomes are likely to
            be sustainable, and in particular, the institutional impact
            of the project was high. However, conservatively it is rated
            as Satisfactory. Key lessons are hereby summarized.
            Concerning Subproject selection and design, and in order to
            maximize the benefits and returns to irrigation and drainage
            (I&D) rehabilitation investments: a) highest priority
            should be given to areas with the more favorable
            agro-climatic conditions for increasing crop productivity;
            b) the lower cost in I&D system rehabilitation works,
            covering a large area and a large number of beneficiaries,
            should be selected; and, the nature of a rehabilitation
            project is such, that the condition of an I&D system may
            change during the time period, from the date of preliminary
            project selection up to the actual start of construction.
            Consequently, the designs, construction contracts, and
            budget allocations need to be flexible enough to accommodate
            the inevitable changes required. As per the development of
            Water Users' Associations (WUAs), it is stipulated that
            adequate resources, consulting services, and time for
            technical assistance have to be provided under the Project
            to establish the WUAs, as well as to provide them with
            support after I&D rehabilitation to initiate the
            agricultural production activities, and achieve the
            system's adequate operation and maintenance (O&M).
            Consequently for this type of investment, this would mean an
            implementation period longer than the usual five years. And,
            in looking at the implementation/organizational
            arrangements, it is mentioned that incorporating the
            Committee of Water Resources (CWR) into the Ministry of
            Agriculture (MOA) and transferring I&D responsibility
            back to CWR, corrected a long standing institutional anomaly
            in the management of the water sector in the country, and,
            CWR is, therefore, in a strong position to manage
            investments for I&D system improvements. Finally,
            lessons regarding cost recovery indicate that a rational
            approach should be used for defining the on-farm and
            off-farm works.

repnme.cdata!:
Kazakstan - Irrigation and Drainage
            Improvement Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The main objectives of the Irrigation
            and Drainage Improvement Project are to: 1) promote
            sustainable irrigated agricultural production through
            irrigation and drainage rehabilitation, improved water
            management, and better operation and maintenance; 2)
            introduce improved agricultural practices and farmers'
            information services; and 3) strengthen irrigation and
            environmental agencies. The project will include the
            following components: 1) rehabilitation of irrigation and
            drainage systems; 2) promotion of agricultural development
            on privatized farms including pilots for farmers'
            participatory training and information services as well as
            farm restructuring; and 3) institution building comprising:
            (a) support for the project implementation unit; (b)
            strengthening of environmental capacity; and (c) study of
            the feasibility of privatizing irrigation management for a
            typical canal command area.
